awd_titl_txt: NSF ERC for Green Air Transportation
awd_abstract_narration:
The Planning Grants for Engineering Research Centers competition was run as a pilot solicitation within the ERC program. Planning grants are not The Planning Grants for Engineering Research Centers competition was run as a pilot solicitation within the ERC program. Planning grants are not required as part of the full ERC competition, but intended to build capacity among teams to plan for convergent, center-scale engineering research. 

This project enables planning of a transdisciplinary research consortium for electric aircraft with broad community stakeholder involvement, to explore innovative next-generation aircraft concepts for vertical and short takeoff/landings. These new electric aircraft designs offer ultra-high efficiency, very low noise and zero-direct air pollution emissions; i.e., a green alternative over conventional aircraft and their supporting infrastructure. Electric aircraft can provide city planners with new options for mixed urban transportation systems.  This consortium serves to conduct convergent, multidisciplinary research for electric aircraft, engage the public on their community benefits, educate students from all walks of life, train the next-generation workforce, and foster an innovation ecosystem based on green aerospace technologies. 

Through next-generation electric aircraft concepts, this project develops a multidisciplinary strategy for protecting the environment and enabling increased transportation mobility that has significant advantages over conventional transportation systems.  Through a series of workshops, the project develops a roadmap with experts from many disciplines and professions, including aeronautics, material science, acoustics, autonomous control, public policy, law, and the aerospace industry.  Building upon the technology for coflow jet active flow control, the planning for the consortium addresses technical challenges for electric aircraft, including aircraft noise mitigation via reduced propeller disk loading, interactive virtual simulations of full electric aircraft systems, high-energy density batteries and high-power supercapacitors, lightweight high-heat conductivity materials, high-power density and efficient micro-compressor actuators, distributed propulsion, flight control, and safety systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Engineering Education and Centers

por.por_cntn:
NSF ERC for Green Air Transportation

Planning Grant, NSF Award #1936888

 Project Outcome Report

 

Gecheng Zha, University of Miami, FL,  gzha@miami.edu  

Gerardo Olivares, Wichita State University

Louis Cattafesta, Florida State University

Richard Gaeta, Oklahoma State University

 

Through this planning grant project for NSF ERC for Green Air Transportation, we have formed a team of 11 universities across the United States. This team  is the backbones for the proposed NSF ERC.  We have achieved the proposed  goal to identify the technical and educational challenges, establish the ERC roadmap, form a team of experts, develop the strategy to integrate the stakeholder community, and establish the framework of the ERC. The final proposal to NSF for the  ERC for Green Air Transportation Ecosystem was submitted on Oct.2, 2020.

 

The major activities of the project include:  

1)     Held the first workshop for the NSF ERC for Green Air Transportation on March 2-3, 2020 at the University of Miami.  Over 30 faculty members from 7 universities with multi-disciplines attended the workshop and presented their proposed contributions  for the ERC.

2)     Weekly meeting for the lead universities  to address all the organizational issues and engage with all the university teams. 

3)     Preliminary  research on the Green Air Transportation Ecosystem to address the system of systems, aerodynamics, propulsion, materials, structures, flight control, flight safety, power electronics, energy storage, cryogenics, superconductivity, aeroacoustics noise, economics, marketing, public policy, communication, education, regulations, culture diversity, and work force development.

As an example of the transformative eV/STOL aircraft systems studied in this project, the attached image shows  a high efficiency tandem wing tailless eV/STOL aircraft system enabled by coflow jet (CFJ) flow control. The figure  displays  the Mach number contours and streamlines at cruise condition simulated by our high order CFD code. The system efficiency is enhanced by the tip vortex capturing mechanism due to coflow jet flow control, resulting in an extraordinarily high  cruise efficiency of  CL=1.6 and CL/(CD+Pc)=14.27 (Pc is the CFJ power consumption). The typical  lift coefficient of conventional subsonic aircraft is CL<0.6. They would be stalled to cruise with CL=1.6 or would have enormous drag. Details of this aircraft system study can be found in AIAA paper   2021-1823. 

4)     After the intensive preparation work, the preliminary ERC proposal entitled ?Green Air Transportation Ecosystem? was completed and submitted to NSF on Oct. 2, 2020.     

 


Last Modified: 01/13/2022
Modified by: Gecheng Zha

Image
  • Mach number contours and streamlines at cruise condition simulated. The system efficiency is enhanced by the tip vortex capturing mechanism due to coflow jet flow control, resulting in an extraordinarily high cruise efficiency of CL=1.6 and CL/(CD+Pc)=14.27 (Pc the CFJ power coefficient).
    Yan Ren, Gecheng Zha
    Copyrighted
    Gecheng Zha
    Tailless Tandem Wing eV/STOL Aircraft Enhanced by Coflow Jet Flow Control

NSF ERC for Green Air Transportation 

Planning Grant, NSF Award #1936888

 Project Outcome Report

 

Gecheng Zha, University of Miami, FL,  gzha@miami.edu  

Gerardo Olivares, Wichita State University

Louis Cattafesta, Florida State University

Richard Gaeta, Oklahoma State University

 

Through this planning grant project for NSF ERC for Green Air Transportation, we have formed a team of 11 universities across the United States. This team  is the backbones for the proposed NSF ERC.  We have achieved the proposed  goal to identify the technical and educational challenges, establish the ERC roadmap, form a team of experts, develop the strategy to integrate the stakeholder community, and establish the framework of the ERC. The final proposal to NSF for the  ERC for Green Air Transportation Ecosystem was submitted on Oct.2, 2020.

 

The major activities of the project include:  

1)     Held the first workshop for the NSF ERC for Green Air Transportation on March 2-3, 2020 at the University of Miami.  Over 30 faculty members from 7 universities with multi-disciplines attended the workshop and presented their proposed contributions  for the ERC.

2)     Weekly meeting for the lead universities  to address all the organizational issues and engage with all the university teams. 

3)     Preliminary  research on the Green Air Transportation Ecosystem to address the system of systems, aerodynamics, propulsion, materials, structures, flight control, flight safety, power electronics, energy storage, cryogenics, superconductivity, aeroacoustics noise, economics, marketing, public policy, communication, education, regulations, culture diversity, and work force development.

As an example of the transformative eV/STOL aircraft systems studied in this project, the attached image shows  a high efficiency tandem wing tailless eV/STOL aircraft system enabled by coflow jet (CFJ) flow control. The figure  displays  the Mach number contours and streamlines at cruise condition simulated by our high order CFD code. The system efficiency is enhanced by the tip vortex capturing mechanism due to coflow jet flow control, resulting in an extraordinarily high  cruise efficiency of  CL=1.6 and CL/(CD+Pc)=14.27 (Pc is the CFJ power consumption). The typical  lift coefficient of conventional subsonic aircraft is CL<0.6. They would be stalled to cruise with CL=1.6 or would have enormous drag. Details of this aircraft system study can be found in AIAA paper   2021-1823. 

4)     After the intensive preparation work, the preliminary ERC proposal entitled ?Green Air Transportation Ecosystem? was completed and submitted to NSF on Oct. 2, 2020.
